summary: HCVcc in culture medium was sensitive to heat and could be inactivated in 8 and 4 min when incubated at 60°C and 65°C, respectively. at 56°C, 40 min were required to eliminate HCVcc infectivity. the ability of HCVcc to survive ambient temperatures warrants precautions in handling and disposing of objects and materials that may have been contaminated with HCV. HCV affects an estimated 170 million people worldwide and is a global health problem. several related viruses in the family Flaviviridae can be readily cultured in vitro, e.g., bovine viral diarrhoea virus (BVDV, genus Pestivirus) have been used as surrogates for HCV to study the inactivation process. a cell culture system based on a molecular clone, JFH-1, offers the opportunity of evaluating the reliable procedures for inactivating HCV.
